commentBody:
I like lavender and sandalwood, but that's just my two scents.

(I've posted this penny of times before.)

Hi all, 8 days left to nominate your favorite puzzles of 2024, for the Puzzle of the Year awards. This is one of the last reminders! Put your choices of worthy contenders as REPLIES to this message. There are four categories: 
M-W
Thursday
Fri-Sat
Sun
We need the date of the puzzle(s), names of constructors, and (optional) your reasons for nominating your choice(s). You can nominate as many as you like. The first reply to this post will be my recap of information as to dates, rules for voting, etc. Thanks for participating! -- John Ezra, Cat Lady Margaret, Eric Hougland.

With the 2024 puzzle of the year voting soon to occur (see John Ezra‚Äôs reminder), it‚Äôs time for me to start a fresh list to scribble down my faves for 2025. Kareem, yours will start the list!

I love themes that act in slightly varying ways throughout the puzzle.

The best laugh was just prior to getting 98A/117A, when I said to myself ‚Äúbut hang on, there‚Äôs no quarter!‚Äù  Hah!

That was fun! I really like when each theme answer plays out differently. It keeps things from becoming too easy once you figure out the trick. 

Took me longer than I‚Äôd like to admit to get the NOQUARTER/PERCENT pair, but now I think it‚Äôs genius.

The hardest thing about Sundays for us phone solvers is navigating a larger puzzle on a tiny screen. That being said, I enjoyed today‚Äôs puzzle a lot, even with all the zooming and panning! Good mix of challenge and reward, with some clever twists.

Scheherazade is a Persian queen, and the story collection called the "Arabian nights" is so called only in English, on the whim of the publisher of the first English translation. It goes by the title "Thousand and one nights" in every other language of culture. It is a translation from the French ‚Äî bowdlerized ‚Äî version of Antoine Galland (1704). Galland's translation is based on a Mameluke Egyptian MS translated in turn from a Turkish MS translated in turn from Persian. Two tales not found in Galland's source ‚Äî or anywhere else ‚Äî are those of Aladdin and Ali Baba. Galland's French translation is the first known appearance of either in world literature, and in Galland, Ali Baba is identified as Persian, not Arabian (Aladdin is Chinese). Galland is suspected of having created both Ali Baba and Aladdin on his own.

As to the Washington airport, it's located in a city whose formal name is SeaTac.
What better New. Year's gift for solvers than a NYT Sunday rebus puzzle. Thank you Kareem and Will!
I put numbers (1/5/10) in the coin boxes and couldn‚Äôt figure out why the puzzle wasn‚Äôt solved ‚Ä¶
How is ‚Äústarts to boil‚Äù = SEERED?

Delightfully tricky, but I am of two minds on the tricks not being consistent. 

Didn‚Äôt realize Teri Garr had died.
WELCOME BACK, WILL! So glad to see your name again.
The rebus haters were out in force on Thursday.  They're certain to be heard from today.

You know what else works for 72A [Away from work, for short?] instead of OOO? Out. Out works. 

Of course that gives you YuDA for 67D, which sounds weird, but then it is *Weird* Al Yankovic, isn‚Äôt it. And at 1am, while your husband and cat snore in gentle harmony, having boxed you into about two square feet of bed space, you swear that in all those odd abbreviations you see blinking on LED matrix signs along overpasses you‚Äôve seen (you‚Äôll swear to it), ‚ÄúDNGR! WTCH OUT! SNW CHNGNG TONITE TO ‚Ä¶ SLT!‚Äù

We drove in SLT earlier today and it was DNGRS. 

A very enjoyable Sunday puzzle. Thank you, Kareem.

Mr Ayas, thank you for not giving up on this charming puzzle! There was a delightful flow about it for me, and perfect enjoyment in figuring out the rebuses. I have to add that I was especially thrilled in seeing all the musical references sprinkled throughout. So it's when you listen to Duran Duran that you get your ideas, eh? I saw them in concert last year and it was a blast; they're in great form. But here I can't resist posting Led Zep's "NO QUARTER" for those who want to end the week rocking out (it's still Saturday night...) https://youtu.be/_BZLM2j8p5E?feature=shared Thank you again! (And wishing all here a beautiful week ahead.)
This puzzle is ingenious!
Great puzzle, Kareem!  Very clever theme and fun to solve.
SEATAC  airport is halfway between SEAttle and TAComa.
Annoying that the online version did not accept numerals in this ingenious puzzle.   Took me awhile to sort that out!

The rebuses for this were a slam dunk once I read the puzzle title‚Äîor were they?  I have a mistake(s?), and I have spent at least ytnewt minutes looking for it (them?).  Everything was a hair off for me throughout the puzzle, especially the naticks, but Mr. Ayas said he meant to break some rules, so they were not surprises.  I've got a game coming up, and sooner or later I will get back to the puzzle and give it another go before I give up.

Is it cold where you are?

Fun puzzle. 

Except I had a lot of trouble with the clue for 62A as that is not a sign I ever see (it's been ages since pennies were in circulation in Canada -- now we just round up or down when using cash).

Oh, that Washington. Doh. Lots of fun solving this one, though I suspect it's going to be tough for the overseas solvers. And any puzzle with BB KING in it is more than okay by me. I just recently learned the Beale Street connection to his name, but naturally do not recall where. And then I fell down a rabbit hole. When Love Comes to Town https://youtu.be/_TGU35i8czo?si=FdAGGuBkZjg2wP2G

If Vlad was a wealthy car collector living in Boston, his neighbors would say, "Yeah, that's Vlad the Impailah's Impalas.." It's also great to see the Trevi Fountain in here mere days after the Times's article on what Italian authorities do with all the coins tossed in there. In 2023, 2 million Euro were collected from the fountain, much of which went to Caritas, an organization that runs soup kitchens in Rome. And of course, it's very apt to have Trevi Fountain in a puzzle about coins. (It's still unbelievable to me that "Half Dollar" from a couple days ago was a NYT debut). I believe my wife made a wish to the Djinn of Trevi Fountain the one time we visited, that Jason Momoa "bares it all" in his next film. She has not expressed the same desire regarding BB King, Slash, Curly, Al Gore, Shia Laboeuf, Rambo, or even Yoda. I can see why, he's a handsome fella, although those hair extensions in Aquaman were a bit of a put-on. Do you think if Aquaman is forced to, er, aviate he'd fly to Sea-Tac? Times on Trevi: https://www.nytimes.com/2025/01/01/world/europe/rome-coins-trevi-fountain-caritas.html?searchResultPosition=1 Lastly, can someone explain [Start to boil] --> SEERED? There's the lack of agreement in tenses, and also I think of seered as what happens if you overstay your tanning bed time, or what you do to a lamb steak. Can one seer a liquid?

The thrill is not gone!  And not just because the great BBKING popped up in this puzzle.  I had a lot of fun with this one.  I thought the theme was clever.  It became clear to me at TR(five)OUNTAIN because I remembered Roman Holiday, although I did try to work in Bocca Della Verita for a few seconds. I also liked SPIRITS for gin and djinn.

Bonus points for including a reference to NADINE Gordimer, the fine novelist from South Africa who was equally important as an anti-apartheid activist.  It‚Äôs always a pleasure when a great artistic talent is also a great human being.
Can someone please explain how ‚Äúpercent‚Äù was related to the ‚Äúno quarter‚Äù clue?
Nickelback was the best band ever.. I‚Äôm so glad their greatness was enshrined in the crossword.  Just kidding
I smiled when I realized that "Washington airport, informally" had two answers that shared all their vowels in same positions ‚Äî rEAgAn and sEAtAC ‚Äî but I'd picked the wrong one!
Gees, I hate finding out my favourite people have died via the crossword. RIP Teri Garr.

I found this puzzle to be fun and breezy, but I have an ongoing quibble with the editing team regarding formatting.

For the fourth time in four weeks (or three times in 8 days), there‚Äôs been a ‚Äúbidirectional‚Äù puzzle where there are answers squares that read differently across than down.

Two of the crosswords allowed for entering those squares as ‚Äúacross/down‚Äù (i.e. ‚ÄúI/ERNST‚Äù and ‚ÄúPH/F‚Äù), while the other two didn‚Äôt accept that formatting (i.e. no go for ‚Äú-/L‚Äù, and ‚ÄúEVIF/FIVE‚Äù).

I prefer entering bidirectional answers as ‚Äúacross/down‚Äù, and IMO it should be accepted unless there‚Äôs a very good reason not to.

As I commented on Thursday, that while the puzzles that have less permissible formatting have been mercifully breezy, their mere existence leaves me paranoid when spending minutes fiddling squares on any bidirectional crossword that it might be the formatting rather than other answers that are incorrect.

Could the editors always accept the ‚ÄúAcross/Down‚Äù formatting or maybe clarify the circumstances in which they wouldn‚Äôt accept it? It would save me minutes‚Äî minutes!‚Äî of my time.

I was one of those that struggled with the formatting. I liked the idea of putting in numbers, as I thought it depicted the coins more effectively, but moreover the TR(EVIF)OUNTAIN/FABEVIF cross made no apparent sense to me when spelled out. 

When I did not get the Congratulations! I proceeded to change all numbers to words, but still no success. I then returned to numbers for the rebuses, and underwent the much-dreaded flyspecking. After several passes I came upon SUVARA/SALTS which I changed to SUVARI/SILTS and still no happy music!

I gingerly changed for a third time all of the rebuses to words (including the awful EVIF) and ...TADA!

Highly enjoyable despite the long drawn-out ending!

I know some people love the rebus and reverse rebus and take a 90-degree turn on a clue.  I'm not one of them.  I seriously wish you'd put a notation on the puzzle that it's a gimmicky puzzle or with rebuses and I'll just skip it for the day and save myself the grief.  I love a challenge, but this is not at all enjoyable.

(1) 1/4 is a fraction‚Äînot a percent.

(2) What is ‚Äúseered‚Äù??‚Äîdo you mean ‚Äúseared‚Äù?  (which is not really correct either‚Äîsorta like item (1) ).

(3) The rebus crossings are a mess.

How this got published I‚Äôll never know.
Good one! I liked it.

Clever theme with excellent execution.  Strong clueing with a few groaners ('urning'), but hey, that's a lot of squares to fill and they were easy to get off of crosses.

If I had one concern, it would be whether or not the range of the constructor's musical taste is reflected here - no sane mind could handle both Duran Duran and Nickelback.
Had to create an account for my first comment: I freaking loved this puzzle. Took me 80 minutes but I loved every one of them. Hope to see more of yours Kareem!
Love, love, love, love, loved it! Thank you Mr. Ayas ~ hope to see another Kareem/Kane inspired puzzle soon. Best for 2025 to you both.

I clocked the first part of the theme within the first two minutes, which is rare for me. I enjoyed uncovering the second component of the theme more gradually, and overall I had a decent time. Unfortunately, I had to spend several minutes figuring out that I incorrectly had SUVARA instead of SUVARI, which felt particularly unfair given that SALTS also made sense with the crossing clue and I've certainly never heard of said actor.

And while we're at it, URNING is a truly absurd bit of fill. Oh well.

Pretty easy puzzle but I wasn't crazy about the theme execution:

1. Coin graphics were not clear or distinct.
2. Revealer for the dime, while certainly not necessary, appears far too much later down in the puzzle.
3. Maybe just me, but doesn't the "no quarter" revealer clue seem wrong?   It implies the right answer is "quarter percent", which obviously ain't 1/4.  Sure you could say he or she means to use "25", but that would seem very stretchy.

Apologies if these have already been addressed.

Fun quick puzzle but didn't love.  :(

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
A wonderfully clever puzzle that made great use of both a theme and wordplay. Great job!

Thanks Kareem Ayas for this puzzle, and great to see Will Shortz back in the saddle! Woohoo! Double treat. 

I imagine Kareem with [Citizen?] Kane, late at night, coins glinting on sidewalks and gutters, fallen from peoples‚Äô hands and pockets, but there were NO QUARTERs!

BARRY (80D) - has appeared eight times in the Modern Era (the Shortz Era) and sixteen times in the Pre-Shortz Era according to XWordInfo.

But how many times has BARRY appeared in the Wordplay comments?

spend quite a bit of time trying to figure out my ‚Äúmistakes‚Äù, and ended up pressing ‚ÄúCheck Puzzle‚Äù - only to find out that the issue was my circled entries were in number form (1, 5, 10) instead of word form (ONE, ‚ÄúEVIF‚Äù, TEN)

for a puzzle like this, where there‚Äôs clearly multiple ways to write the answer, i‚Äôd expect these forms to be accepted!!

I know I'll hate myself in the morning, but could somebody explain 38A (Increases ---> UBS)? I've been poring over the finished-but-no-finished puzzle for what seems like hours and this is the only weird thing I can find. (And I've read all the comments as of maybe 15 minutes ago so I've got my rebuses all in text.)
I've traveled to Italy twice,but I must say I have never been to Trefi Veountain. 78-Across does justify the ugly stain on an otherwise pleasant Sunday puzzle.

Enjoyed it. Must agree with others that PERCENT is tortured but the rest was ok. 

A plausible exposure to US culture made the dime turning, penny leaving fine and at least for me the TREVIFOUNTAIN was a gimme. The Colloseum wouldn‚Äôt fit. 

I feel that rebuses should work even when left empty. That would only be fair. 

A decent Sunday morning puzzle. 

Thanks.
I don‚Äôt think Romeo was such a tough guy
Please stop putting clue answers in the Wordplay picture!
In today's mini, 7-across, with a photographic lens, applies to a greatly reduced scope.  Something like "economics" would have fit the clue better.

This is not a comment on the puzzle, which I greatly enjoyed, although I didn‚Äôt get the PERCENT/NOQUARTER link until I read @Steve L‚Äôs excellent ‚Äúto a five-year-old‚Äù explanation.  

I‚Äôm writing to say that I was all set to reward myself with attending the ACP Tournament this year for the first time, after years of solving the NYT crossword and reading the Comments from all of you.  I‚Äôll admit to feeling nervous about the opportunity to meet so many people who I‚Äôve only known through this column, but my curiosity and interest finally overcame my fear of possible rejection and I made plans to finally go.  

Alas, life got in the way, as it often does, this time in a good way. I‚Äôll be occupied with caring for my grandson after my daughter has her second child (my first granddaughter) in late March.  While I‚Äôm obviously looking forward to that, I‚Äôm going to miss the opportunity to meet many of you there.  Usually I tell myself that there‚Äôs always next year, but at 72 I know how things can change from one year to the next. I‚Äôll have to settle for just being there in SPIRIT instead. üôÇ

Ye gods, I got the trick! This would never have happened a year ago. I'm so happy about this üòÄ. There must be something to the theory that doing puzzles improves cognitive ability.

I needed some lookups for the proper names, it took me forever to understand SLO and its clue, and I did not know the word TAMP before. But other than that the solve was pretty smooth, if longer than my usual Sunday, at almost an hour.
Great puzzle, really enjoyed it!

Kareem Ayas, this was brilliant.  I don't come to the column too often anymore and always either to spread the smug or offer my truly humble awe and gratitude for feats of construction like this.  Today is the latter.  Thank you for your persistence, woohoo!

After all the discussion the other day about Lola and whether she (he?) was a showgirl or just hanging at a club in SoHo, I enjoyed seeing Weird Al make an appearance today‚Ä¶

I saw the little runt sitting there on a log
I asked him his name and in a raspy voice he said, "Yoda"
Mabrook Kareem! A enjoyable Sunday solve, your talents are impressive.
I‚Äôve never heard of a ‚Äúbuy get one free‚Äù sales promotion.

I was going to call out that the town is actually named Elon College, not Elon, and that would have been true not that long ago.

The town of Elon is right down the road from me.  The town used to be named Elon College, and I hadn‚Äôt realized until I just looked it up, that town name was officially changed to just Elon when  the school Elon College became Elon University.  It makes sense of course, and I guess I just missed it in the times it has been an answer in the crossword.

Complaints notwithstanding, this puzzle made a lot of cents.

Sorry.

Lovely Sunday! I'm always a fan of rebuses (rebusi?) because it is one of those rare puzzle theme types where you can't really "accidentally" solve it without getting the theme. This one actually felt tricky for some reason, as I kept putting in answers that slightly fit (AMPED instead of HYPER, DON instead of LON). In the end if flowed nicely though, and I solved well under my average time!
This was something special. Congrats and thank you, Kareem!!
Thank you Kareem for the enjoyable puzzle. It provided some nice aha moments.

My goodness, that was fun. I figured the theme was coin related but my first issue was not knowing how much each coin was worth, followed by struggling to parse the connected clues. My way in was NICKELBACK. That blimmin song is now stuck in my head. Thanks.

The Roman landmark took the longest, as I had fat thumbed LOL for Mr Chaney. I‚Äôve been twice to Rome, each time the FOUNTAIN has been empty behind scaffold for repairs. Maybe third time lucky?

I watched Elvis for the first time last night, which happily gave me the answer to 106A. Good film. Talk about an unreliable narrator. Tom Hanks magnificent as always.

Ka-ching! The answers to this Sunday crossword fell like pennies from heaven...took about the quarter of my usual time to complete, though a few almost made me stop on a dime. Would have been fun to have worked in the four President's names but I imagine that would have involved quite a bit of change. Thanks Kareem for doing your Sunday best, to coin a phrase!

I finished and didn't get the "congrats"..I checked and double-checked, then went to the NYT answer key, which had all the circles spelled out just as I had on my puzzle. In essence, my answers were exactly the same as the answer key....still no congrats...maybe someone can explain what I'm missing. 

Thanks for any help...I'm on a very long streak!

I try to be sure and post when I particularly enjoy a puzzle. 
This is easily one of my favorite Sunday puzzles for quite some time. Loved that each rebus had a different "gimmick" and many of the clues were quite clever.
Just very well done in my opinion.
Thanks, Kareem!

Truly amazing puzzle - just well above my pay grade. One fifteen letter answer that dawned on me today: DEMOLITIONDERBY That pretty much describes my solving experience. End of streak. No big deal. Oh... and my puzzle find today. A Sunday from January 19, 1997 by B. Klahn with the title: "Presidential Punditry." Some theme answers: DISSEDHILLARY ALGORERHYTHMS CHELSEAGRAMMAR And there were more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/19/1997&g=78&d=A I'll head back to my home planet. See you later. ...

Loved this puzzle! Not so difficult but original, quirky and perky! If it referenced a writer or celeb I didn‚Äôt know, i could usually get the grid filled going the other way. I almost try not to fill my brain with obscure sports or film celebrities so my 61-year old brain will remember new work stuff! So thanks for that! Fun!

Great theme idea and execution, Kareem. I love that each one works in a different manner. I'll admit that I had to think hard to understand 117A, making it my favorite. 18D [Mess (around)]: https://youtu.be/2KwUALcwbHQ?si=zKVdB9G0qcmGh1NC
Rebuses are terrible. Please stop using them.

Well, with the sparkling cleverness baked into the theme, and a solve ‚Äì by not being a trudge ‚Äì that allowed the theme to shine, this puzzle kicked up a lot of happiness.  

There were enough hitches in the fill-in to satisfy my brain‚Äôs workout ethic as well.  So, a superb outing for me.  Layered on top of were:

‚Ä¢	Admiration for the grid-making skill.  A clean answer set ‚Äì it‚Äôs actually calming to scan the filled-in grid.  Plus, the spark from 13 answers we‚Äôve never seen before in the Times puzzle, and they‚Äôre all good!:   BARES IT ALL, BAT PUP, BUY ONE GET ONE FREE, DUCATI, FAB FIVE, FELT IT, HAIR EXTENSIONS, NO QUARTER, SUVARI, TAKE A PENNY LEAVE A PENNY, TANNING BED, TREVI FOUNTAIN.  Wow!
‚Ä¢	Inspiration from Kareem‚Äôs notes.  He started with a simple Thursday theme idea based on TURN ON A DIME, but scrapped that after coming across TAKE A PENNY, LEAVE A PENNY, realizing he could make something better. Then he worked and chiseled, improved and polished ‚Äì went through 19 iterations of a Sunday grid ‚Äì 19! ‚Äì to make it just right.  That‚Äôs an artist, whose motivation is beauty.  That is uplifting.

So, Kareem, thank you for happifying my brain and soul this morning.  I loved this!

Strands thread.  Please no spoilers until after the View All Replies button: 

Strands #308
‚ÄúCold snap‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµüîµ

Seasonal.
Help?   How does "seerer" mean "start to boil" (17 down)?
and how does "tee" answer "love all"?    (I thought that might be "zen"...  but...)
excellent puzzle today--incredibly clever clues that really made me crunch my brain, and clever, non-intrusive (lol) rebuses. took longer than my average but also had fewer lookups than usual.

Am I the first to say I found this really hard? Not a complaint! So many reference to things and people I don't know. But I solved all the clues that were not names, even SEE RED! But I did get bogged down in looking up answers. Not a complaint! 

I'm not experienced enough to have been able to solve the theme. I'm used to "Trevi", not TREFI so that didn't help. And not knowing instinctively that ten relates to dime and penny is one cent (I do know, but not as a reflex thought) made it harder. 

The explanations for five-year olds show me that I'm not yet on the right wavelength. Maybe later.

That was fun, though obscure (to me) proper names me required a couple of look-ups.
Unusually, I had to solve the rebus entry at 32A and work back from there to figure out what the "revealer" at 62A was. What on Earth is TAKE A PENNY LEAVE A PENNY about?
Likewise, I had to solve 54A TREVI FOUNTAIN as a reverse revealer for 78A NICKELBACK, of whom I'd vaguely heard and had just enough crosses to get an Aha! moment.

I'm also not convinced that TURN ON A DIME involves a [pivot without warning]. Isn't it more about being quickly responsive and manoeuvrable? Or has the metaphor extended in US usage?

Solved this one in about 30 minutes, which was half what yesterday's cost me.

Got and liked the theme quite a bit---until the NOQUARTER, 1/4, PERCENT. I'll have to scan the column and the comments to see if I've missed something, but that trio just leaves me cold. Kinda like the theme wasn't quite there, and neither the constructor nor the editor(s) could figure out how to make it whole.

Not sure what else to say. Liked BATPUP, though I wish it had been clued "Babe in a cave".
Still don't see how EVIF and FIVE are both FIVE?

Oh boy, another creative theme.

As usual I just did the puzzle and then read the notes in an effort to understand the theme.

The expression I usually see is ‚ÄúBuy one get one free‚Äù,  often abbreviated as BOGO.  But the puzzle uses ‚ÄúBuy get one free‚Äù.  I didn‚Äôt spend a lot of time on it, but had to wonder if this was part of the cutesy theme or an idiosyncratic hack to make it fit.  

Apparently it was the latter as no explanation in the notes.

And for the life of me I don‚Äôt see how you get from ‚Äú1/4‚Äù to PERCENT, even with reference to NOQUARTER

That one hit my sweet spot for a Sunday challenge with coffee. Some pleasing incidences of having to make minor alterations and a sequence of enjoyable little ahas with the coins. Being a Londoner living in Ireland I was happy not to encounter any baseball or basketball related clues though I've rampaged through enough of the crossword archive now to have learnt a reasonable amount about these sports. I'm generally OK with the NFL üòÑ

Fun gimmick.

I was stuck for the longest time with BIN at 29D and BATBOY at 10D.

I really enjoyed the theme. And there were a number of clues  with several good answers ..like 102D...but also a bunch of crosswordese..like otoe, tot, aver...I guess because the theme was so demanding. That said, really fun to do!

Before piping in about how 

SEERED is just simply *not*
like getting mad (simmered, maybe..?)
I took a last look.

Oh, right. See red. 
D‚Äôoh!

When I was young I saw a dish
next to a cash register with a note -

Have a penny? Leave a penny.
Need a penny? Take a penny.

I can still *see* that little piece of paper
and wonder if it should have been clear 
back then that I would love
wordplay in all its forms, forevermore.

Lovely Sunday! 
Thank you Kareem!
What happened to the first O in BOGO? That was a bit jerry-rigged.
This puzzle is poorly edited. There are several questionable clues, and then there's the five/evif thing which is just a goofy little tapdance to make this trite gimmick work.
Excellent puzzle!

Hoo boy. This puzzle was Thursday-worthy, and I expect we'll see the comments roiling. Bat-shi . . . er, -pup crazy.

I love it. More puzzles, please, Kareem Ayas.

Aerate is a word... but not the correct one,

Fun solve and BATPUP: Who knew!

Thank you Kareem
I don‚Äôt get how to enter the FIVE/EVIF in that one blank so it‚Äôll accept it as done‚Ä¶
Fun Sunday puzzle!

So, so good! Loved the variety with the theme. The support surrounding all the potentially tricky bits was so well considered, that even things like the backward FIVE came out really smoothly. The polishing time put in on this grid shows!
Enjoyed it very much. Excellent work.

Fun puzzle.

I wasn't sure that I really had the theme, especially when I got the "Keep trying" message.

It turned out it was a typo in one of the rebus blocks.

Also, thank you for not using the name of that vicious ex-president as the airport nickname.

Happy new year!

Kareem Ayas,

What a great puzzle!  What a great idea!  And even a great name!  (Not yours, the puzzle's: All Things Change.)

Two-and-a-half years to create!  Amazing!  I hope you don't ask an accountant to compute your pay-per-hour on the construction.  Clearly this was a labor of love!

My only complaint is that you revealed your earlier idea for a four-way TURNS ON A DIME Thursday puzzle.  That would have been great!
Perhaps there is still hope for it?!?

A very fast Sunday for me - a little too fast, really. I like Sunday to take at least two cups of coffee or one hour, whichever is longer. 

I didn't get that the theme involved coins until I read the column, though - and the NOQUARTER / PERCENT pairing seems kind of sketchy to me, or maybe inconsistent.

Still, it was clever. Thanks for the fun!
Oh man, this was a super fun puzzle. Thanks Kareem!
Awesome puzzle Kareem! Thanks!

Enjoyed today's puzzle! My only nitpick is that when I had finished correcting my *other* errors, the puzzle still didn't complete for me as I had entered digits into the circled spaces, which seems like it fit the theme better and I think should have counted.

Na na na na na na na na 
Na na na na na na na na
Batpup!

Love it when a theme works in different ways! Great puzzle!

Anyone else picturing Suvari riding her Ducati while eating rumaki and playing Jumanji?

OMG Will is back?!?!?!?

I missed you Sir Will

I have the puzzle filled in.  I "got it" with the 78A/54A pair.  The 117 and 98A were less sticky.  

I had to guess at the Italian motorcycle, since VESPA was clearly not the answer there.  I'm mainly here to find out what I have wrong at 62A, because I can't make it out.  This is disappointing to me, but I have spent enough  of my breakfast (cold oatmeal, cold coffee, twice)...I even went so far as to step out to the garaged Subaru and get a NICKEL to examine.  I also have something puzzling (ha ha...not) in the NE at 17D.  
So:

I loved this puzzle except for one completely wrong clue -- 42 Across. The crossword conflation of Greek eta and English H comes back to bite the constructor.  While the English transliterations of both Homer and Herodotus  start with H and the Greek capital letter eta is written as the shape H, there is no eta in either name. The H sound in each name is written as a backward apostrophe before the vowel (called a rough breathing), not an independent letter. Neither name uses eta as a vowel.   Sorry, kids.

The "like you were a five-year-old" explanation:

In the first three theme clues, TEN stands in for a dime, ONE for a penny, and FIVE for a nickel.

The companion clues tell you how the gimmick works for each of those coins.

In 101A, you are told to turn on the dime for 19A.  In 19A, you reach the TEN rebus and turn downward and complete the answer, HAIR EXTENSIONS.

In 32A, you follow the advice in 62A.  You TAKE A PENNY and LEAVE A PENNY.  So the first "one" (i.e. penny)  in BUY (one) GET ONE FREE is taken (so it's not there) and the second "one" is left there.  You have to take one and leave one.

In 54A, you have the FIVE rebus in there, working fine with the cross (FAB FIVE), but backwards for TREVI FOUNTAIN.  The companion answer, 78A, is NICKELBACK, telling you that the FIVE has to be read backwards.

98A, which solves to NO QUARTER, is the companion clue for 117A (PERCENT).   QUARTER, like the other coins, represents its value in cents, which is 25.  So the clue for 117A, [1/4], solves to 25 PERCENT, but since you are advised to enter it with "no quarter", you omit the "25", and are left with PERCENT as your fill.

It's totally logical if you follow the steps.  If you don't follow the logic, read this over again until it sinks it.  If it doesn't make sense to you, keep at it; it just hasn't clicked for you yet.

@Rachel and cent is short for percent, or 1/100. So 1/4 minus a quarter is zero.

@Lisa the clues/answers are a math/language hybrid. The math is that 1/4 is also 25 percent. The language is that 1/4 is a quarter, and a quarter is a US coin worth 25 cents. So write out ‚Äú25 PERCENT,‚Äù take away the 25 (‚Äúno quarter‚Äù), and you are left with just PERCENT. Yes, it‚Äôs complicated and convoluted but it is correct in the context of NYT crossword clues and answers.

@Theresa 

Explained previously, recopied just for you:


The "like you were a five-year-old" explanation:

In the first three theme clues, TEN stands in for a dime, ONE for a penny, and FIVE for a nickel.

The companion clues tell you how the gimmick works for each of those coins.

In 101A, you are told to turn on the dime for 19A.  In 19A, you reach the TEN rebus and turn downward and complete the answer, HAIR EXTENSIONS.

In 32A, you follow the advice in 62A.  You TAKE A PENNY and LEAVE A PENNY.  So the first "one" (i.e. penny)  in BUY (one) GET ONE FREE is taken (so it's not there) and the second "one" is left there.  You have to take one and leave one.

In 54A, you have the FIVE rebus in there, working fine with the cross (FAB FIVE), but backwards for TREVI FOUNTAIN.  The companion answer, 78A, is NICKELBACK, telling you that the FIVE has to be read backwards.

98A, which solves to NO QUARTER, is the companion clue for 117A (PERCENT).   QUARTER, like the other coins, represents its value in cents, which is 25.  So the clue for 117A, [1/4], solves to 25 PERCENT, but since you are advised to enter it with "no quarter", you omit the "25", and are left with PERCENT as your fill.

It's totally logical if you follow the steps.  If you don't follow the logic, read this over again until it sinks it.  If it doesn't make sense to you, keep at it; it just hasn't clicked for you yet.

The evidence is mainly that doing puzzles improves your ability to do those specific puzzles.

I don't do these on my phone, but I've read it recommended (by Eric ? ) to look at your answers in list form. It can be easier to spot any typos.

@Alyson

if flyspecking in sequence through the puzzle doesn't find an error, you might try the "list" view- at the top (oh, depending on your device/ browser/ app), click on the leftmost icon and you'll see the clues and answers in a kind of list form. On the one hand, a disadvantage is you can't as instantly check on the crosses as you can in the normal grid; but sometimes, seeing it laid out like that helps find an error. And if you don't find one, I guess you just go back to the grid and very carefully scroll through...

One thing I find is that sometimes I'll sort of blankly accept and ignore an answer that I didn't like but that *kinda sorta works*... and the cross either kinda sorta works too or I didn't catch it. Sometimes I have to screech to a halt and pause and rethink an "OK" answer that seems weird, sometimes crossed with a completely unknown word which I just took as something I didn't know! This happened in a recent puzzle where I put MOSTREAD instead of MUSTREAD for a Down entry somewhere in the middle-ish of that puzzle. The cross was a proper name or odd word which I just kept going past over and over again and ignoring. So sometimes you have to say, "maybe my unease with this answer is because it's just wrong!"

Those are the tips I can give.

Perhaps I had a bit of ADD myself at the time: Automatic Distracted Dismissal of my misgivings about a clue/ answer. Misgivings which I blamed on mediocre construction/ editing for that entry, lol!

Good wordhunting.
